body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" p "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the largest integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2013^n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2013! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" q "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the largest integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" m "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2014^m "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2014! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" r "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the largest integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" s "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2015^s "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2015! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" Find the largest integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" [(p+1)(q-2)(r+3)]^x "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2016! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To solve this, we will use the function
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N(m,n) = \text{ largest integer }\, x\, \text{ such that }\, m^x\, \text{ divides }\, n!"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
which is well-known to have the properties
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
p \text{ prime} \implies N(p,n) = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \left\lfloor\frac{n}{p^k}\right\rfloor \\
N(m^k,n) = \left\lfloor\frac{1}{k}N(m,n)\right\rfloor \\
N\left(\text{lcm}\{m_1,m_2,\ldots,m_k\},n\right) = \min\left\{N(m_1,n), N(m_2,n), \ldots, N(m_k,n)\right\}\}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Turning toward the problem at hand,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
p &= N(2013, 2013) \\
 &= N(3\times 11\times 61, 2013) \\
 &= \min\left\{N(3,2013), N(11,2013), N(61,2013)\right\} \\
 &= N(61,2013) \\
 &= 33 \\ 
 { } \\
q &= N(2014, 2014) \\
 &= N(2\times 19\times 53, 2014) \\
 &= \min\left\{N(2,2014), N(19,2014), N(53,2014)\right\} \\
 &= N(53,2014) \\
 &= 38 \\
 { } \\
r &= N(2015, 2015) \\
 &= N(5\times 13\times 31, 2015) \\
 &= \min\left\{N(5,2015), N(13,2015), N(31,2015)\right\} \\
 &= N(31,2015) \\
 &= 65 + 2 \\
 &= 67
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"so that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
N\Big((p+1)(q-2)(r+3),2016\Big) 
 &= N\Big(2^4\times 3^2\times 5\times 7\times 17,2016\Big) \\
 &= \min\left\{\left\lfloor\frac{1}{4}N(2,2016)\right\rfloor, \left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}N(3,2016)\right\rfloor, N(5,2016), N(7,2016), N(17,2016)\right\} \\
 &= \min\left\{\left\lfloor\frac{1}{4}N(2,2016)\right\rfloor, \left\lfloor\frac{1}{2}N(3,2016)\right\rfloor, N(17,2016)\right\} \\
 &= \min\{502, 502, 124\} \\
 &= \boxed{124}
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2013 AMC10B - Problem 23
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AB = 13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC = 14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CA = 15"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Distinct points "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"F"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" lie on segments "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{BC} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{CA} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{DE} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", respectively, such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{AD}  \\bot\\overline{BC} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{DE} \\bot\\overline{AC} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{AF} \\bot \\overline{BF} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The length of segment "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\overline{DF} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\frac{m}{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are relatively prime positive integers. What is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m + n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle{AFB}=\angle{ADB}=90^{\circ}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", quadrilateral "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABDF"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is cyclic. It follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle{ADE}=\angle{ABF}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle{AFB}=\angle{AED}=90\implies "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" triangles "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABF \text{ and} ADE "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are similar. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It follows that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AF=(13)(\frac{4}{5}), BF=(13)(\frac{3}{5})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By Ptolemy, we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13DF+(5)(13)(\frac{4}{5})=(12)(13)(\frac{3}{5})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Divide the whole equation by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to obtain  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"DF=\frac{16}{5}\implies{16+5= \boxed{21}}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Ptolemy Theorem","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" gives a relationship between the side lengths and the diagonals of a cyclic quadrilateral; it is the equality case of Ptolemy's Inequality. Ptolemy's Theorem frequently shows up as an intermediate step in problems involving inscribed figures. The statement is as follows:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given a cyclic quadrilateral "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABCD"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with side lengths "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{a},{b},{c},{d}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and diagonals "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{e},{f}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ac+bd=ef."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2013C13
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Before you, Brilli the Ant places 2013 urns labelled 1 through 2013. In urn "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" i-1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  white balls and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2013 - i "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  black balls. If you randomly choose an urn, and then randomly choose 13 balls without replacement, the probability that all balls are the same color is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\frac{a}{b} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are positive coprime integers. What is the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a + b "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\leq i\leq13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have the probability of getting 13 balls to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{{{2013-i} \choose 13}}{{{2012} \choose 13}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (choosing from the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2013-i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" black balls), while for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2001\leq i\leq2013"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have the probability to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{{{i-1} \choose 13}} {{2012} \choose 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (Choosing from the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" white balls). "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Adding up the probabilities in these ranges gives us: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{13} {{2013-i} \choose 13}+\displaystyle \sum_{i=2001}^{2013}{{i-1} \choose 13}}{{2012} \choose 13}=2*\frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{13} {{2013-i} \choose 13}}{{2012} \choose 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(Note that the 2 summations are equivalent). "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note that adding "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" {{2000}\choose 14}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^{13} {{2013-i} \choose 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{2013}\choose 14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so the above summation is equivalent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2*\frac{{{2013}\choose 14}-{{2000}\choose 14}}{{{2012} \choose 13}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14\leq i \leq 2000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have the probability of getting 13 balls to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{{{2013-i} \choose 13}+{{i-1} \choose 13}}{{2012} \choose 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (choosing from the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2013-i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" black balls or the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" white balls)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Adding up the probabilities in this range then gives us: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac {\displaystyle \sum_{i=14}^{2000} {{2013-i} \choose 13}+\displaystyle \sum_{i=14}^{2000}{{i-1} \choose 13}} {{{2012} \choose 13}}=2*\frac {\displaystyle \sum_{i=13}^{1999} {{i} \choose 13}} {{{2012} \choose 13}}=2*\frac {{{2000} \choose 14}} {{{2012} \choose 13}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(Firstly, the two summations are equivalent and secondly, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{i=14}^{2000}{{i-1} \choose 13}=\displaystyle \sum_{i=13}^{1999} {{i} \choose 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":")"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Adding up all the probabilities for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \leq i \leq 2013"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we then get: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2*\frac{ { {2013}\choose 14} -{ {2000} \choose 14} } {{{2012} \choose 13}} + 2*\frac {{{2000} \choose 14}} {{{2012} \choose 13}}=2*\frac{{2013}\choose 14}{{2012}\choose 13}=2*\frac{2013}{14}=\frac{2013}{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Dividing the total sum of the probabilities above by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2013"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have the expected probability that the 13 balls taken are all the same colour is then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The sum of the reduced fraction's numerator and denominator is then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+7=\fbox{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I'm not referring to how 'bad' it is, or not. I'm asking for an alternative interpretation, which would allow us to simplify the calculations.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            That massive calculation really isn't that bad. That sum is sometimes known as the hockey stick theorem in pascal's triangle. 

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Is there a simpler explanation which doesn't require you to deal with such massive calculations? There should be some reason why the answer is so nice."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{1}{7} = \frac{2}{14} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here is a general solution. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the number of balls per urn, so that there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" urns in total. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the number of balls we select, and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_{\mbox{white}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the probability of choosing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" balls in a row and having them be all white. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For an urn with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j \ge m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" white balls, there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{n}{m}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ways of choosing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" balls, of which "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{j}{m}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of those feature all balls being white.  For urns with fewer white balls there are no ways of picking "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" white balls."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Averaging this over all urns gives:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned}
P_{\mbox{white}} &= {1 \over n+1} \sum_{j=m}^{n} ( \dbinom{j}{m} / \dbinom{n}{m} ) \\
 &= {1 \over n+1} {1 \over \binom{n}{m}} \sum_{j=m}^{n} \dbinom{j}{m} \\
 &= {1 \over n+1} {1 \over \binom{n}{m}} \dbinom{n+1}{m+1} \\
 &=  {1 \over n+1} {m!(n-m)! \over n!} {(n+1)! \over (m+1)!(n-m)!} \\
 &= {1 \over m+1}
\end{aligned}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
where the third step comes from Pascal's Christmas Stocking, and can easily be proven by induction considering that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{n+1}{m+1} = \binom{n}{m} + \binom{n}{m+1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", i.e. the sum of the two entries above it in Pascal's Triangle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Surprisingly the result only depends on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For this actual problem where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m=13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , and we want to double the answer since we want the probability of white added to the probability of black, we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 \over 14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{1 \over 7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(i)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denote the probability that we would get 13 balls of same colour from urn "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". We know that we can either select "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" white balls out of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i - 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" white balls or we can select "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" black balls from "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2013 - i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" black balls."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Rightarrow"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(i)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{{i - 1 \choose 13} + {2013 - i \choose 13}}{{2012 \choose 13}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By Baye's theorem, required probability = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{1}{2013} \displaystyle \sum_{1 = 1}^{2013} P(i) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2013}\displaystyle \sum_{1 = 1}^{2013}\frac{{i - 1 \choose 13} + {2013 - i \choose 13}}{{2012 \choose 13}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (Note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{6 \choose 13} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":")"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2013} \frac{2{2013 \choose 14}}{{2012 \choose 13}} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"="},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{7} \Rightarrow a + b = \fbox{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Indeed this was what I was hinting at in my initial comment. Here's another hint:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" Use the technique of a distinguished element, to relate this to a problem on 2014 balls.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Lets write out the first couple terms"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Urn 1","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" = 0 White 2012 Black"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Urn 2","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" = 1 White 2011 Black"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Urn 3","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" = 2 White 2010 Black"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now write the probabilities we get "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{{2012 \choose 13}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" times"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{2012 \choose 13}+...+({1999 \choose 13}+{13\choose 13})+...+({13 \choose 13}+{1999\choose 13})+...+{2012 \choose 13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we see that the mess on top can be simplified with the hockey stick identity. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It simplifies into "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 \times {2013 \choose 14}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2013}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" chance of choosing a specific urn"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bringing everything together we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{2}{2013}\times\frac{{2013 \choose 14}}{{2012 \choose 13}} = \frac{1}{7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1+7 = \boxed{8}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Is there a simpler explanation which doesn't require you to deal with such massive calculations? There should be some reason why the answer is so nice."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{1}{7} = \frac{2}{14} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 2013-(is)-Gon
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A regular 2013-gon is constructed with a side-length of one inch. To the nearest whole number, what is the distance (in inches) between the center of the 2013-gon and one of its vertices?"}]}]}

title: 2013! Sorry I forgot what is the present year
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a,b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are natural numbers such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2013 = b^{2} - a^{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  , then the minimum possible  value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is:"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2013 = (b+a)(b-a)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=>(b+a) & (b-a) both are odd numbers.
=> One of a,b is even and the other is odd."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2013 = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3\times 11\times 61"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The following possibilities arise:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i) a+b = 61 ; b-a = 33"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=> "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{ a = 14 , b = 47 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ii) a+b = 671 ; b-a = 3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=> "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{ a = 334 , b = 337 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"iii) a+b = 61 ; b-a = 33"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=> "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{ a = 86 , b = 97 }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, the minimum possible value of "},{"type":"text","text":"ab","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is in "},{"type":"text","text":"case (i)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" where both "},{"type":"text","text":"a","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"text","text":"b","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" are the least. Hence the minimum possible value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{ab = 47\times14 = 658}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Its a KVPY 2013 question."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(b - a) (b + a) = 2013 = 3 × 11 × 61."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab minimum when b - a = 33 and,."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b + a = 61."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"implies,a = 14 and b is 47."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, minimum of ab = 14 × 47 = 658."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a²-b²=2013"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a+b)(a-b)=61*33"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b=61……………..(1)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a-b=33……………….(2)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"After solving these equ the value of"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=47,b=14"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab=658"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the number of consecutive \"0\"s that can be found at the end of the decimal expansion of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2014!"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This can be computed per the Factorial Trailing Zero formula:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Z = \Sigma_{k=1}^{\lfloor \log_{5}(n) \rfloor} \lfloor \frac{n}{5^k} \rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = 2014"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Sigma_{k=1}^{\lfloor \log_{5}(2014) \rfloor} \lfloor \frac{2014}{5^k} \rfloor = \boxed{501}."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Compute the remainder when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2014^{2014} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1000 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2014^{2014}\equiv 14^{2014}\pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By Euler's Theorem:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(14^{\phi(1000)}\right)^5=\left(14^{400}\right)^5=14^{2000}\equiv 1^5=1 \pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14^{2014}= 14^{2000}\cdot 14^{14}\equiv 14^{14} =2^{14}\cdot 7^{14}\pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I don't know a short-cut for the rest calculation. However, if one doesn't want to touch calculator, then he can work out the rest step by step multiplying and then taking modulo "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{14}=2^{10}\cdot 2^4=1024\cdot 16\equiv 24\cdot 16 =384 \pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7^{14}=2401\cdot 7^{10}\equiv 401\cdot 7 \cdot 7^9\equiv 807\cdot 7^9=\cdot\cdot\cdot=407\cdot 7\equiv 849 \pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore ~~~ 2014^{2014}\equiv 14^{14}=2^{14}\cdot 7^{14}\equiv 384\cdot 849 = 326016\equiv \fbox{016}\pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            you are very lucky, because euler's theorem create here nothing but non sense. Euler results states that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{\phi(n)}\equiv \pmod n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" only when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"gcd(a,n)=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". I dont see here "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"gcd(14,1000)=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            But (14,2000) is equal to 2,not 1, so you can't use it directly.You can use that EVERY even number on the power of 100 gives remainder 376 when divided by 1000.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I like your use of Euler's Theorem, it saved a lot of computation. At that point, I'd use my method above (or below) to compute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14^{14}\pmod{1000}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 2014 AMC 10
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/RA7uNpPeg5-2014-amc10-b.PNG?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Six regular hexagons surround a regular hexagon of side length 1 as shown above. What is the area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\triangle ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/iZzyw9PHFc-b170525.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle ADE"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a right triangle with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle DAE = 30^\circ"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AE=\cos 30^\circ = \dfrac {\sqrt 3}2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AC = 4 \times \dfrac {\sqrt 3}2 = 2\sqrt 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle ABC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is given by:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} [ABC] & = \frac 12 AB \times AC \times \sin \angle A \\ & = \frac 12 \times 2\sqrt 3 \times 2\sqrt 3 \times \frac {\sqrt 3}2 \\ & = \boxed{3\sqrt 3} \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2014 AMC 12B #18
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 are to be arranged in a circle. An arrangement is bad if it is not true that for every n from 1 to 15 one can find a subset of the numbers that appear consecutively on the circle that sum to n. Arrangements that differ only by a rotation or a reflection are considered the same. How many different bad arrangements are there? "}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We see that there are 5! total ways to arrange the numbers. However, we can always rotate these numbers so that, for example, the number 1 is always at the top of the circle. Thus, there are only 4! ways under rotation, which is not difficult to list out. We systematically list out all 24 cases. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, we must examine if they satisfy the conditions. We can see that by choosing one number at a time, we can always obtain subsets with sums 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. By choosing the full circle, we can obtain 15. By choosing everything except for 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5, we can obtain subsets with sums of 10, 11, 12, 13, and 14. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means that we now only need to check for 6, 7, 8, and 9. However, once we have found a set summing to 6, we can choose everything else and obtain a set summing to 9, and similarly for 7 and 8. Thus, we only need to check each case for whether or not we can obtain 6 or 7. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We find that there are only 4 arrangements that satisfy these conditions. However, each of these is a reflection of another. We divide by 2 for these reflections to obtain a final answer of 2."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: LET US LEARN SOMETHINGNEW!!(2014)
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/solvable/39e4b06e3f.fb96549631.alP3nK.jpg?width=250"}},{"type":"text","text":"
I deposited 2014 in HDFC bank which gives interest @ 6% per annum. So for how many years I must keep Rs. 2014 in bank so that my money gets doubled (or) comes very near to the doubled amount."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hint and Directions:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) Let us assume I had Rs.50 with me on which I am receiving interest at particular rate, after 5 years the amount turns Rs.99.88 and after 6 years it turns up to Rs. 101."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) Thus according to question the year in which the amount gets doubled or comes nearest to the amount when compared to other years. Hence, the answer will be 5 years and not 6 years because in five years the amount including interest has come very close."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3) The question can be cracked in less than 2 seconds, so better not use calculators!!"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The problem can be cracked by the well-renowned "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\huge{RULE OF 72}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"According to rule of 72:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A given amount will be doubled in 72/x years compounded annually where x is the interest provided on the amount."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(it is not applicable with 2% interest rate compounded for 36 years)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Just divide 72 by the interest rate, and you will get the answer as 72/6"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\huge{=12}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hope, this helps all of you to really learn something new!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":""KNOWLEDGE MULTIPLIES WHEN SHARED""}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
